bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, August 23, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]

div1.p: Hanson discusses a report he received from the President of Colombia expressing his concerns about yellow fever and describes areas in need of clean up as well as the time and funds a general campaign will require.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, August 23, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]
div1.opener:
(3) Colombia (3)
COPY
(Letterhead)
HOTEL PALATINO
MEDELLIN-COLOMBIA
Medellin, 23 de Agosto de 1923.
My dear Col. Russell:
div1.p:
We arrived in Medellin this evening, and have come here on
account of a report which President Nel Ospina gave me of yellow
fever at Ebejico. I gained the impression from his remarks that
there actually was an epidemic at that place now. The President
did not ask me outright to come here but it seemed evident that he
was quite interested, which I think is confirmed by the telegram
which he sent to the “Gobernedor” of this place. The typewritten
copy which Dr. Emiliano Henao M. showed me covered a full page of
this size and if I can secure a copy of it I will send it to you.

On account of the fact that we will have a seven or eight
hour ride by horse or mule back from here we have come “light” and I
left my typewriter and other paraphernalia at Puerto Berrio. I de-
cided to come at this time as we could do it with the least loss of
time on our way down. We do not expect to be back up this way for
some months, i.e., after we have established our work on the
river and on the coast.

From the information which I am gathering it appears almost
certain that there has been yellow fever in several points in the
upper Magdelena district, such as at Ibagué, Ebéjico and Cisneras
on this R.R. Apparently it has about burned out at many of these
points. Casceres on the Cauca River is said to have had about 20
-2-
cases reported recently. This to my way of reasoning indicates
the necessity of clearing up Cartagena, Barranquilla and the coast,
because if it has not already reached there it soon will, as I stated
in my letter from Rogota, relaying down via the river ports.

Both the Director of Public Health and the President are un-
easy about this situation and have given me full authority to go
ahead with the work wherever I think necessary.

On the way down we made an inspection at Girardat and found
88% of the houses inspected showing stegamyia. I expect to put
three men to work there (they claim 19000 population); they have a
large transient population, and it can serve as a distributing point
if infected.

As stated in my previous letter we go from here to Barranca-
Bermeja and then to Bucaramanga and then to the coast. The minimum
expense will be $10,000.00 per month for from 6 to 12 months, for the
general campaign expense.

I am quite impatient about this delay in getting a general
campaign under way, but there seems no way to avoid it.

I have written this on both sides to avoid weight for the areal
mail. Will write or cable according to the urgency of the case.
